newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot resid prices mostly gain with gas.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot resid prices mostly gain with gas.

text.p: U.S. spot residual fuel prices mostly gained Wednesday in lackluster trade, boosted by another sharp rally in natural gas values and still-stable crude, industry sources said.

"There's a little life in resid. People are starting to think we'll see low sulphur demand building because of high gas prices, but there's still no real load," said one cash trader, noting relatively mild East Coast temperatures.
In New York Harbor, physical one percent jumped 50 cents to $14.75-15.00 a barrel. May paper also was done 50 cents higher at $15.25, with bidders still left at that number.
NYH June one percent paper sold between $15.85 and $16, also up more than 50 cents on the day.
NYH 0.3 percent high pour notionally firmed more than a quarter to $15.50-75, boosted more by the one percent rally than any unfilled utility demand, traders said.
New York high sulphurs were up only slightly, capped by talk some European high sulphur may be heading to the harbor.
At the U.S. Gulf, a planned refinery maintenance outage and good bunker interest helped firm three percent by about 50 cents to $13.75-14.00.
USG one percent was unchanged at $14.50-75, still underpinned by prospects for more utility interest in Florida.
A Florida utility awarded the one percent portion of its tender at $15.68 (delivered, May 12-June 3).

New York city gate swing gas prices firmed almost a dime Wednesday to the low-$2.60s/mmBtu, or about $16.50 a barrel equivalent. Gas at Henry Hub, the NYMEX delivery point, gained a similar amount to the mid-$2.30s/mmBtu, or $14.81 a barrel.
